item.title: Hawks back in box seat - The Advertiser
item.description:
Hawks back in box seat  The Advertiser

This was personal. It was the first time Hawk maestro Alastair Clarkson had gone up against his former boss Chris Fagan since the Tasmanian jumped ship for Brisbane after nine years in the Hawks nest. After being challenged strongly in the second quarter, when they were in front by only two points, and pushed hard in the third, the Hawks were able to kick away for a 17.11 (113) to 11.9 (75) win in front of 10,553 fans at UTAS Stadium. It delivered Clarkson a moral victory over his great mate Fagan and Hawthorn’s second win on the trot, after downing Melbourne in a thriller at the MCG a week...

item.title: Harris takes home chocolates in marathon - The Advertiser
item.description:
Harris takes home chocolates in marathon  The Advertiser

The Launceston World University representative in the half marathon continued to build momentum in the full 42.195km event, claiming a debut win in the race that also doubles as the Tasmanian marathon championships ahead of Wagga’s Mick Donges in 2hr 28min and 56 sec. Donges and two-time winner Dave Criniti — also of NSW — established an early lead in the race at the famous chocolate factory but the 26-year-old Harris slowly caught up to them and passed them with just under 14km to go. “In the end I think I put a couple of minutes into them but I didn’t hit the lead until the 28km mark,” he...

item.title: End of an era as 173yo Birchalls book store to close - ABC News
item.description:
End of an era as 173yo Birchalls book store to close  ABC News

Birchalls, Australia's oldest book shop, is preparing to close after more than 170 years of trading in Launceston, Tasmania. The store was established in 1844 and will cease trading in the coming months after being put up for sale in March last year. While the premises sold in November, no buyer has stepped up to take over the business and its four Tasmanian outlets. Managing director Graeme Tilley said it was the end of an era. Photo: Many people will be saddened to see Burchalls close, says Launceston Mayor Albert van Zetten. (ABC News: Carla Howarth) "We get customers from all over Austr...

item.title: Man dead in Tasmanian highway crash - The Advertiser
item.description:
Man dead in Tasmanian highway crash  The Advertiser

The Kia wagon carrying six people crashed with a Ford Falcon sedan about 10km south of Perth on Sunday morning. The man driving the Kia died at the scene and a female passenger has been flown to hospital in Hobart. A man driving the Ford was taken to Launceston General Hospital. Police have put road diversions in place while they investigate the crash.

item.title: Man seriously injured in Christmas tree fall - The Advertiser
item.description:
Man seriously injured in Christmas tree fall  The Advertiser

Emergency services were called to Launceston’s Brisbane Street Mall at about 11.30pm on Wednesday after receiving reports a man had fallen from the city council Christmas tree. The 33-year-old was taken to the Royal Hobart Hospital in a serious condition. Inspector Michael Johnston from Launceston Police reminded revellers to stay safe when drinking alcohol, particularly during the festive season. “We want people to have fun but not put their lives, or other people’s lives at risk,” Inspector Johnston said. Police are investigating the circumstances which led to the man falling from the tree.

item.title: Tassie women hoping for big break at AFLW draft combine - ABC News
item.description:
Tassie women hoping for big break at AFLW draft combine  ABC News

As a cricketer, Courtney Webb is used to spending time in the middle, so it's no surprise the 17-year-old is comfortable being caught between two sports. Tassie girls trying out for AFLW: - Daria Bannister, Launceston FC - Loveth Ochayi, Launceston FC - Georgia Hill, Launceston FC - Courtney Webb, Kingborough Tigers FC Tomorrow, the teenager will be one of four Tasmanians among almost 50 aspiring footballers at the first ever women's draft combine in Melbourne. Photo: Courtney Webb hopes to play top level AFL and cricket for as long as possible. (Facebook: Launceston Women's Football Club) ...

item.title: Petrol jumps up to 20 cents a litre, $1.40 benchmark expected - ABC News
item.description:
Petrol jumps up to 20 cents a litre, $1.40 benchmark expected  ABC News

Petrol prices have soared by as much as 20 cents a litre over the past few days in some parts of the country, with $1.40 a litre seen as a new benchmark for January. Figures from the Australian Institute of Petroleum show the national average price of unleaded rose 2.2 cents over the week to Sunday, hitting 128.3 cents per litre. But the national average masks extreme regional variations. At $1.22 per litre, Melbourne's prices were relatively steady and only barely above the terminal gate wholesale price that service stations are paying. However, residents in Sydney and Adelaide were being ...

item.title: Do not approach - The Australian
item.description:
Do not approach  The Australian

The wayward male seal, nicknamed Mr Lou-Seal by Tasmania Police officers, was first spotted at 5.45am this morning in Penquite Road in the Launceston suburb of Newstead. He proceeded to climb onto a parked Toyota sedan, causing thousands of dollars in damage to the windscreen and roof, and then fell asleep on the driveway. Tasmania Police correspondent Sargent Renee Stewart confirmed authorities have tranquillised the creature and are awaiting his removal and relocation by Parks & Wildlife officers. “We’ve sent extra police officers down there to assist with the physical lifting side of thi...

item.title: Launceston joins gigabit family - The Australian
item.description:
Launceston joins gigabit family  The Australian

Launtel is using the NBN’s fibre-to-the-premises footprint, which extends across the city, to offer interested parties 1000 megabit per second (Mbps) speeds at commercially viable rates. For businesses in the city, the speed and quality of the service on offer would rival what’s available in Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan. The telco’s founder, Damian Ivereigh, said the full-fibre footprint of the NBN might have been cut short in Tasmania and around the nation but it was incumbent on operators to make the most of the technology. “The fibre has always been ready for gigabit services and we ar...

item.title: Pizza shop workers' fresh take on anti-SSM billboard - ABC News
item.description:
Pizza shop workers' fresh take on anti-SSM billboard  ABC News

The owners of a Tasmanian pizza shop have altered the meaning of an anti-same-sex-marriage billboard next to their business, a day after a Hobart hotel distanced itself from a billboard atop its premises. Employees at Wiseguise Pizza, in the Launceston suburb of Mowbray, started painting the brick wall adjacent to the "It's OK to say no" sign, adding the words "to pineapple on pizza". Worker Ben Barwick said the shop did not want to take a political stance. "We are painting the side of our building, not on the sign, and basically turning that into a bit of humour," he said. "It's a huge deb...

item.title: Hawks, Saints unchanged, Tippett late out - The Advertiser
item.description:
Hawks, Saints unchanged, Tippett late out  The Advertiser

Hawthorn and St Kilda kick off today’s matches, doing battle in Launceston before Carlton and winless Sydney take to the MCG. Brisbane host Port Adelaide at the Gabba in the twilight fixture before North Melbourne host Gold Coast at Etihad Stadium tonight. Over in Perth it’s the big derby between West Coast and Fremantle. Follow all the action live in our blog below. GET STATS AND SUPERCOACH SCORES HERE

item.title: Life returns to island paradise - The Australian
item.description:
Life returns to island paradise  The Australian

Their Circa Morris Nunn-designed home, affectionately known as the Courtyard House, in Peddie Drive, Dilston, on the Tamar River 15-minutes out of Launceston, is listed for a hefty $2.1 million. “An island paradise” that combines the best of everything in Australia, Jennifer Edis says Tasmania is “so hot right now” for a good reason. “The decreasing cost of flights and increased frequency of flights everyday (Launceston is Australia’s ninth busiest domestic airport) adds to the convenience of reaching Tasmania,” she says. “It’s close enough to matter but far enough to feel like a world away...

item.title: Draw! Giants, Hawks in last-second thriller - The Advertiser
item.description:
Draw! Giants, Hawks in last-second thriller  The Advertiser

The Giants led by two goals in time-on but the Hawks fought their way back into the contest until they tied the scores at 14.13 (97) to GWS 15.7 (97) with a Will Langford goal at the 32-minute mark. BLOG: SATURDAY’S ROUND 16 AFL ACTION When the ball returned to the centre with only seconds left to play, the Hawks surged forward knowing a behind would clinch it. When Hawk Ryan Burton punched the ball through for a point the Hawk army raised the roof in jubilation, only to be stunned into silence. The siren had sounded before the ball crossed the line — but it could not be heard in the roar f...

item.title: Targa Tasmania a family affair for passionate fans - ABC News
item.description:
Targa Tasmania a family affair for passionate fans  ABC News

Long-time Targa Tasmania spectator David Biggelaar reckons the love of cars was bred into him by his father. Leading his son and daughter between a line of idling Porsches, Ferraris and Lamborghinis near the entrance to the Sideling in north-east Tasmania, he was doing his best to pass on the passion. It was the first day of the rally, covering nearly 74 kilometres in seven stages, with the finish line in Hobart on Saturday. The Launceston father said he came to watch rally stages of the on-road competition in Tasmania each year. Sections of public roads are closed for scheduled time trials...

item.title: Where could you afford to buy if you diverted your super? - ABC News
item.description:
Where could you afford to buy if you diverted your super?  ABC News

The Federal Government is toying with the idea of letting young people divert compulsory superannuation payments to help save for a house. Let's see where that would get you. We've crunched the numbers based on what an average 25 to 34-year-old earns (according to the ABS), which is around $75,000 a year. Taking a 9.5 per cent compulsory super contribution, plus a dollar-for-dollar post-tax co-contribution, invested for three years at 3.2 per cent per annum, we figure you'd have a deposit of about $45,545 after three years. So where could you afford to live? (Spoiler alert: not anywhere nea...

item.title: Easter armed robbery in Launceston - The Advertiser
item.description:
Easter armed robbery in Launceston  The Advertiser

The 69-year-old victim was in his driveway today about 7.10am when two men wearing dark clothing and covering their faces confronted him. The man was threatened with what is believed to have been a small handgun. An ensuing struggle left the victim in hospital suffering non-life threatening injuries. The bandits stole valuables from the victim’s car before running into bushland near the home. Investigations are ongoing and anyone who may have witnessed the incident or may have any information is urged to contact the Launceston Criminal Investigation Branch on 6777 3915 or Crime Stoppers on ...

item.title: Alpaca 'slaughter' by roaming dogs leaves hobby farmer devastated - ABC News
item.description:
Alpaca 'slaughter' by roaming dogs leaves hobby farmer devastated  ABC News

A northern Tasmanian hobby farmer has described the killing of his alpacas by dogs as like a "slaughter". Early Sunday morning about 20 livestock, including sheep and alpacas, were killed in the attacks at four properties in the Launceston suburb of St Leonards. Hobby farmer John Binns said seven of his alpacas were killed, including six pregnant females. He said he was shocked by the scene after being alerted by his neighbour. "I went out to find that there was five of them in one paddock and they were slaughtered, it was all around the head," Mr Binns said. He found a male alpaca in anoth...

item.title: Cambridge a Launceston template - The Australian
item.description:
Cambridge a Launceston template  The Australian

Mr Taylor recently toured Cambridge with University of Tasmania vice-chancellor Peter Rathjen in a bid to understand how a compact between local and federal governments and the university was driving bullish jobs growth and a booming local ­economy. “Cambridge tells us a lot about what needs to happen here. There is 8 per cent jobs growth. The overall employment growth in the UK is closer to 1 per cent. That is not coming from primarily from students and research; most of it is coming from the private sector attaching itself to the university,” said Mr Taylor. “That connection between the i...

item.title: Obituaries for July 8, 2017 - The Advertiser
item.description:
Obituaries for July 8, 2017  The Advertiser

Bomber pilot, teacher Born: June 14, 1922; Launceston, Tasmania Died: June 2, 2017; Adelaide Education: Launceston Church Grammar School, University of Tasmania Achievements: Bomber pilot and teacher; founder of Community Aid Abroad in SA Family: survived by Christobel, children Christopher, Rosemary and Stephen DAVID Mattingley’s heroism in World War II earned him a Distinguished Flying Cross on the spot, but for generations of schoolboys in Adelaide it was his soft-spoken command of the English language, history and literature that was most important. “Dink” was a tall gentleman of impecc...
